questions.question: Q1. What is the effect of correlation between two features on the feature space representation?

answers.a: Correlation can help in identifying the relationship between features.
answers.b: Highly correlated features may provide redundant information.
answers.c: Correlation can affect the shape and orientation of the feature space.

explanations.a: While true, it is not the complete effect of correlation.
explanations.b: Highly correlated features often provide redundant information which can affect model performance.
explanations.c: Correlation affects the shape and orientation of the feature space representation.
explanations.d: This is the most comprehensive answer, covering all aspects.

questions.question: Q2. Is it possible that the addition of a new feature decrease the accuracy of the NN classifier? How?

answers.a: Yes, due to the curse of dimensionality.
answers.b: No, more features always improve accuracy.
answers.c: Yes, because new features can add noise.
answers.d: No, the accuracy remains the same.

explanations.a: Adding new features can increase the dimensionality, which may dilute the effectiveness of each feature.
explanations.b: This is incorrect; more features can sometimes reduce accuracy.
explanations.c: Adding new features can add noise, but the main issue is the curse of dimensionality.
explanations.d: This is incorrect; adding features can change accuracy.

questions.question: Q3. Is it correct that for nearest neighbor classifier, it is always best to have all features scaled to the same range? Show why or give a counter example.

answers.a: Yes, scaling features helps to ensure each feature contributes equally.
answers.b: No, scaling features does not impact NN classifiers.
answers.c: Yes, because unscaled features can dominate the distance calculation.
answers.d: No, sometimes unscaled features provide better results.

explanations.a: Scaling ensures that each feature contributes equally to the distance metric.
explanations.b: This is incorrect; scaling can significantly impact distance calculations.
explanations.c: Unscaled features can dominate the distance calculation, but scaling helps.
explanations.d: Generally, scaling is preferred, making this a less common case.

questions.question: Q4. Can the nearest neighbor classifier be applied to feature vectors of different length? Is it possible to do so if you have a function that takes in two feature vectors (possibly of different lengths), and outputs the similarity/distance between them? Suggest a possible function of this nature, and a classification problem, where it can be applied.

answers.a: Yes, by using a custom distance function like Dynamic Time Warping (DTW).
answers.b: No, all feature vectors must be of the same length.
answers.c: Yes, by padding shorter vectors with zeros.
answers.d: No, using vectors of different lengths would lead to errors.

explanations.a: DTW can handle varying lengths by finding the optimal alignment between feature vectors.
explanations.b: This is incorrect; custom distance functions can handle different lengths.
explanations.c: Padding is a solution but not as effective as using custom distance functions.
explanations.d: This is incorrect; custom distance functions can handle different lengths.
